title: Ryan Hall's Athletic Achievements
content: Ryan is a retired American long distance runner who holds the US record in the half marathon at 59 minutes and 43 seconds. He became the first US runner to break the 1-hour barrier. He also holds the American record in the marathon and is the only American to run sub 2:05, running 2:04:58. Ryan is generally regarded as one of the greatest American distance runners.

title: Ryan Hall's Transformation and Coaching Career
content: Ryan retired in 2016 after a really difficult 4-year period, following the London Olympics, which was plagued by lots of injuries. He’s really transformed his body in a way that is almost difficult to imagine without looking at a picture of him then versus now. Ryan now is a coach. He coaches his wife, who is also a professional runner, and he coaches runners of all category and talent levels through his training program called Run Free Training. He’s written a book called Run The Mile You’re In.

title: Ryan Hall's Physical Strength and Fitness Challenges
content: Ryan is into power lifting and carrying on many extreme feats of physical strength. Some of which we talk about, but many of which you can see on his Instagram account, which Peter can’t recommend that highly enough. For example, his last one was doing a 500 lb deadlift and then immediately running into a 5-minute mile. He didn’t succeed in that. He went 5:22 or something, but he’s going to take another shot at it. We also talk about one of the most crazy of his fitness challenges that he does for himself.

title: Ryan Hall's Mindset and Optimism
content: Ryan is just an incredibly optimistic person. He’s the kind of person who really never seems to let failure get to him in a way that maybe some of us certainly myself would. Peter think’s his optimism is kind of what’s allowed him to bounce back from so many setbacks. In this episode, we talk about his career, but not in the necessarily in the most linear way. His amazing successes and his epic failures. What he’s learned through these experiences. Peter remarks, “this is one of the few podcasts where I really felt like I came into it with kind of a sense of where I wanted to go and I completely came off that. I don’t think that’s a bad thing. I think it just speaks to how much I couldn’t stop wanting to get into details of his training and just how intrigued I have been by his transformation.”

title: Ryan Hall's Background and Training
content: Ryan grew up in Big Bear, CA; it’s at altitude. It was a really cool place to grow up. It’s 2 hours from the beach. It’s one of the few places someone can both surf and snowboard/ ski in the same day. He lived a mile away from snow summit. Many of the best runners in the world come from places that are 7,000 feet altitude, such as Ethiopia and Kenya. So he found himself in the perfect scenario for a distance runner in the sense of being able to live high and train low.

title: Training Cardiovascular System During Formative Years
content: Peter suspects there is something to being in that environment when you’re young, during the formative years of the cardiovascular system. He thinks if one doesn’t push their system hard in the teenage years, it’s very hard to develop it later. Ryan thinks when someone develops their cardio early on, later, they just need little touches here and there.

title: Advantages of Altitude Training
content: Peter thinks it is important that he became interested in looking for ways to improve his training, in the years when he was a swimmer. He looked at the matrix of living high, living low, training high, training low and coming up with what was the optimal scenario. Today, the answer is crystal clear— best results are attained from living high and training low, when it comes to intensity.

title: Training at Altitude vs Sea Level
content: Ryan notes that training at altitude is different from training at sea level. At altitude, he does a lot of intervals to break things up, while at sea level, one can spend a lot of time at race pace. Going down to sea level for workouts felt really good, it worked, and the results were obvious. His wife, Sara, grew up at sea level and has run 2:20 for the marathon, which is the second fastest ever by an American.

title: Marathon Training
content: One of the most important things about marathon training is someone’s threshold. For a 15 mile threshold, Ryan just runs 15 miles at the marathon intensity. He could run 12, 15 miles at 4:48 per mile, which is about marathon pace at 7,000 feet. If he pops down to sea level, maybe he runs a 4:42 pace, 4:40 pace, but he didn’t get a huge conversion from altitude to sea level. Whereas someone like his wife, Sara, who wasn’t as accustomed at altitude, she’ll get maybe 20 seconds a mile where she’s running that much slower at altitude than she would at sea level.

title: Benefits of Living at Altitude
content: Ryan and his wife, Sara, moved to Mammoth Lakes out of college after they graduated from Stanford in 2005. Sara hated living in Mammoth, at 8,000 feet for such a long time. But gradually over time, she’s gotten much, much better at altitude. They have a place in Crested Butte, Colorado, where they’re sleeping at 9,400 feet. Every time she goes up there, they see a massive jump in her fitness just from doing a month up there.

title: Progressive Overload and Switching Up Your Workout Routine
content: Ryan notes that progressive overload is one of the hardest things to do when one is training themself. The challenge of being able to progressively overload doesn’t always mean weight; it can mean sets, reps, reduction in rest time. He loves to see growth and the frustration of not seeing growth. His mind will chew on this for months, and he’ll make little tweaks until he finds it.

title: BFR Training and Weight Training
content: Recently Peter has become obsessed with blow flow restriction (BFR training) and weight training; that becomes another way to progressively overload, using a fraction of the weight one would normally use. See podcast #179 – Jeremy Loenneke, Ph.D.: The science of blood flow restriction—benefits, uses, and what it teaches us about the relationship between muscle size and strength (Oct 11, 2021). Also check out AMA #32 to see how Peter incorporates BFR into his workouts. Ryan notes he has been using BFR training too.

title: Recovery from Injury
content: BFR training is helpful for runners, especially after he got hurt. Ryan was training for the Beijing Olympics. He was at the Olympic training center at Chula Vista, working with a strength coach. He was on one of those vibrating platforms to warm up for squatting. They were great; he was able to warm up and get into a much deeper squat than he ever had gotten into before. But as a runner (most runners are super tight), the ankle mobility wasn’t there. He should not be down in a butt to the ground squat; it’s just not beneficial for distance runners. Long story short, he ended up tweaking the connection to his patella and that bothered him all the way up to Beijing. In Beijing, he was kicking myself so much for getting hurt lifting.

title: Lessons Learned from Competing in the Beijing Olympics
content: Peter recalls that Ryan had a pretty good run in Beijing; he finished 10th. Yea, but for Ryan it wasn’t about what place he finished, it was the sensation of clicking. He wrote a book about that whole experience, so much went into that. Running with Joy: My Daily Journey to the Marathon (published in 2011). But it was also that he wasn’t clicking in training. When things are clicking he feels like Tigger, just bounding along as effortless like, “this is going to be fun…you’re kind of licking your chops”. He didn’t take a big break after running 2:06 at the London Marathon in April 2008. He didn’t take his customary 2 week break where he would put on 10 lbs and not run at all. So then he was just flat for the whole build up to Beijing; he wasn’t right going into that race. It’s interesting talking to scientist at the Olympic training center, prepping for the race. Talking about how hot and humid it’s going to be. This was one of those big life learning experiences for him, where the storyline is— it’s going to be so hot and humid, it’s going to be slow. The race will be won in 2:12, 2:11. They just hearing this story over and over again. He didn’t do what he learned to do after that, which is, “You got to be like the Samurai… you got to be ready for any situation that’s going to come and not expect anything”. “Expect nothing, be ready for anything” – Ryan Hall. He wasn’t in that state of mind, he was thought it was going to be chill for the first mile. Right from the gun, Sammy’s just gone; the guy who ended up winning the gold medal. He just took it out super hard. Mentally, Ryan got hit in the chin with an uppercut, right out of the gate because he wasn’t ready for that scenario at all. So then he got back and was in 60th place and he’s trying to win a medal but thinking, “You don’t win a medal from 60th place”. A lot of competing well in anything is getting excited while you’re out there – Ryan Hall. One has to be holding this snowball of excitement as the race is playing out. He was having the opposite experience of that. He was not where he wanted to be. He was too far back; he couldn’t even see the leaders; the he helicopter was way off in the distance. He had to coach himself through that. And actually how he did that was by encouraging other guys around home, which isn’t a normal tactic. But as he encouraged other people, it encouraged himself.

title: Importance of speed, power, and strength for runners
content: Peter used to have a sign in his office, it was a pace clock that said 4:42. Many, many years ago, they had a treadmill set up to that pace [12.76 mph]. The idea was they had random people show up and run, to see how long they could sustain that pace. They would put a harness around a person’s waist and they’d make them run at 4:42. And these people were getting shot off the back of this treadmill after 30 seconds, 40 seconds, one person made it a minute. Right? The reason Peter put this sign up in his office was because he was put off by the notion that people would say, “Hey man, we’re training for a marathon, not a sprint”. He tried to make the point that if someone wants to win a marathon, it feels like sprinting. It’s one thing to go out and run a marathon and take hours to do it. It’s another thing to go out and win a marathon. If someone is trying to win a marathon, they have to understand the pain that these guys are in. They have to understand what 4:42 means; it is insanity. For Ryan, it’s below his threshold, but his threshold is so high. For Peter, looking at Meb win that race, having seen him in the months prior, running so fast doing tempo repeats while Peter was on his bike, it is really amazing.

title: Running with Meb Keflezighi
content: He and Meb were neighbors training in Mammoth; they lived 400 meters apart; and he’s always been like a big brother to Ryan. He was in that race when Meb won Boston and that was such a special experience. Ryan remembers he was having a bad day that day. He was coming up over Heartbreak Hill and he remembers just yelling at the spectators on the side, asking how Meb was doing when he came past. And they were like, “He was winning when he came past”. Ryan knew if Meb got over Heartbreak Hill in the lead, he was going to win that thing; that was special. Peter notes, it’s hard to believe this was 2014, it was one of those races that is seared into his mind. He remembers it well because he trained at the same place as Meb in San Diego, at Fiesta Island; that’s where all the cycling time trial races are held. Peter would train at Fiesta Island 3-4 days a week; it’s 7 Km and perfectly flat. Meb would do his tempo runs there. Early on a Tuesday or Thursday morning, they’d be the only 2 guys out there; Peter on his bike and Meb running.

title: The Importance of Speed for Distance Runners
content: Ryan and Peter emphasize the importance of speed for distance runners. They believe that distance runners need to have speed to win. Ryan coaches kids to get as fast as they can because they need 49 second speed to be a world-class marathoner. This speed will help them run a great mile and a great 5K. It's all built off speed. Peter works on developing 5K speed and mile speed first, which is directly correlated to sprint speed. He does 50-meter sprints twice a week in the middle of marathon training and is in the weight room to improve his power to weight ratio.

title: Strength Training for Power and Speed
content: Peter and Ryan discuss the importance of strength training for power and speed. They believe that power is essential for all distance runners, and a marathon runner has to have that speed. Meb, a marathon runner, was doing deadlifts to improve his strength to weight ratio. They wanted to avoid hypertrophy, so they did a hex bar deadlift with a high concentric and a dropped eccentric. Meb's strength to body weight ratio for a single rep max was 1.3 when he first started, which is not great. To increase his stride length, he needed to take his maximal force per unit body weight from 1.3 to 2.7.

title: How Strength Factors into Running Form and Speed
content: Peter and Ryan discuss how strength factors into running form and speed. They believe that the harder one hits the ground, the higher one goes, and the further their stride. Meb needed to add four inches to his stride to run the pace he wanted to run in Boston that year. To do that, he needed to increase his maximal force per unit body weight from 1.3 to 2.7. This increase in strength translated to four more inches of stride length.

title: The Importance of Foot Contact and Glute Strength
content: Peter and Ryan discuss the importance of foot contact and glute strength in running. They note that a runner should stomp the ground to put force into it, rather than pawing it like a tiger. They also emphasize the importance of glute strength, which is often underdeveloped in runners. Peter suggests that weight training, particularly the hex bar deadlift, can help improve foot contact and glute strength.

title: Analyzing Running Stride to Improve Speed
content: Peter and Ryan discuss the use of a device called a G flight to analyze running stride and improve speed. The device measures how high someone can jump and their ground contact time, which can be used to determine how well they are able to generate force. Peter suggests that a ground contact time of 0.2-0.25 seconds can increase a runner's speed. He also notes that load dissipation and transfer are important skills for aging individuals, while Ryan wonders how heel strikers like Jim Ryun and Dathan Ritzenhein can run so fast.

title: Running Technique
content: Experts suggest that fore-foot to toe striking is the way we were meant to run. It’s not striking on the heel. Ryan agrees and is interested not in what someone can get away with but what is optimal.

title: Ryan Hall's Running Background
content: Ryan Hall started running when he was 13 years old. His first run was around Big Bear Lake, a 15 mile run. He was suffering the whole time, wearing basketball shoes, and had no idea what he was doing. But that was such a learning experience for him now as a dad of, for myself being like, how do we respond to our kids and their crazy ideas? It changed the trajectory of his entire life.

title: The Mental Aspect of Training
content: Running is very nonlinear. The pain he was feeling at 5 miles; this is a quarter of the distance of 13 miles in terms of effort. The thing about distance running is… what’s going on in your head is hugely important. Turn the mind off and keep putting one foot in front of the other. It sounds so simple and basic. But in the last 5K of the Boston Marathon when he is in a world of pain, there are no profound thoughts going on in his mind.

title: The importance of being in the present moment
content: In moments like that he often turns his brain off and just keeps moving. He gets in trouble when he starts thinking too far down the road. It’s easy to get overwhelmed with the scope of the challenge, especially when trying to do something one has never done before and being in the worst discomfort. That’s what makes people give up and give in. Ryan has found if he can bring himself back to the present moment of what he’s doing right now; there is always enough to get him through the moment. There’s not always enough to get him through all that’s coming down the line. But if he only tries to do what is in front of him, run the mile he is in and bring himself to the present moment, there is always enough to get through that moment. This is why he titled his book Run the Mile You’re In. “You just got to bring yourself back to being present in this moment, and there’s always enough to get you through this moment.” – Ryan Hall

title: Comparing running to swimming— expectations are important in each
content: Peter compares the difficulties of running to swimming. “One of the things about running that strikes me as difficult in that regard is you can’t disassociate yourself from the visual cues of how much lies ahead”. In contrast, when swimming long distances he had a rule to never look up towards short. He would only know he was near land when he started to see the bottom of the ocean. This happens around half a mile from shore.

title: Peter notes the fortitude needed to run the race
content: The example Ryan talked about of being in Beijing, knowing he was in 60th, seeing the helicopter over the leaders a quarter mile up the road. That requires an extra level of mental fortitude to stay competitive in the race. Ryan replies, “it all comes back to getting excited, right? If you’re going to perform well, you’ve got to be excited about how you’re doing…  find something to get excited about in that moment”

title: The Grand Canyon “farmers carry” challenge
content: For example, he was doing a crazy challenge he calls chop wood, carry water. He splits a cord of wood at his house in Flagstaff, and then drives to the Grand Canyon. He runs down to the bottom of the Grand Canyon, holding these 7-gallon water jugs. They weigh about 62 lbs each when they’re full. It’s a 10K (6.3 mile) run down to the bottom of the Grand Canyon; it drops 5,000 feet. He gets to the Colorado river, fills them up and farmer-carries them out of the Grand Canyon. He remembers being down at the bottom and filling up those jugs and just looking up at the trail he had just run down. He thought, “what did I get myself into?” The sun was already getting down super low. And that was the hardest part of the whole challenge for him was just starting back up. Because he knew what was waiting for him; how far he had to go.

title: Ryan's Farmers-Carry Challenge
content: Ryan carried 63 lbs in each hand of water up 6.3 miles up a 7% grade, 5,000 feet. It took him 6 hours. His hands took a beating, but it was more cardio than strength. He would stop every 50 meters or so to put them down; so it was a lot of carries. Peter notes, 'That is actually more insane than your deadlift 500 lbs run a five minute mile attempt, which also was super impressive. But this farmer’s-carry thing is ridiculous.'

title: Reframing Negative Thoughts
content: Ryan had to reframe a lot during his farmers-carry challenge. He initially thought it would take him 4 hours to carry these out; his goal was to beat the sun. But it was already 3 or 4’oclock when he got down to the bottom. He found himself getting frustrated about how it was going. Thoughts of, 'I’m never going to get out of here' were going through his mind. Once he was able to accept all those negative thoughts and then reframe it, then he was able to embrace this really beautiful experience. This was one that was life changing for him. One that he’ll never forget; getting to the top of that canyon and putting those jugs down. How good it felt to finish.

title: The Power of Not Quitting
content: Ryan's farmers-carry challenge was the hardest physical thing Peter could ever imagine doing. Ryan's pace was basically a fast walk. He wanted to make his legs and heart do as much of the work as possible. This was harder than running a marathon because during a marathon his heart rate is around 167. In this challenge it was probably 195, 197. He couldn’t get it over 200. Ryan is right, there is something about saying, 'I’m not going to quit; I’m going to put my head down and I’m going to do this'. When one gets to the other end, it’s pretty remarkable.

title: Training for the Grand Canyon Challenge
content: Ryan trained for the Grand Canyon challenge by doing 20 minute carries every other day. He did 20 minutes with 65 lbs in each hand and 20 minutes of 30 seconds on, 30 seconds off. He trained on flats and could have trained better but he’s a full-time dad, coaches his wife, and has an online training business. He didn’t have time to do hour-long water carries.

title: The Importance of Fueling
content: Ryan knows how important fueling is when doing any kind of ultra stuff. With proper fueling, he could get through anything. He was super specific when he was running professionally and those experiences carried over into the farmer-carry Grand Canyon challenge. One can train their gut to take in stuff. Problems arise when one eats new stuff they’re not used to.

title: Learning from Mistakes
content: Even for modest forms of endurance training, learning the fuel and making dumb mistakes was important. Ryan knew if he took in enough calories and stayed hydrated, he was going to be okay in the Grand Canyon challenge. Problems arise when one eats new stuff they’re not used to.

title: Carbo-loading for a marathon
content: 2 days before a marathon, he’s carbo-loading. The nutritionist he worked with advised him to spread the load out so he wouldn’t feel bloated and terrible the day before the race. He would eat 400 calories of extra carbohydrates for 2 days before the race. Those carbs would be super simple. He wanted to make it easy on his system. He would eat white rice, pasta; he really liked sourdough bread because of its lower glycemic index and it digests easily. Maltodextrin is a carb he likes to take in; it’s a tasteless, liquid calorie. He can mix it with protein powder, shake it up, and shoot it down. But you has to be careful, he’s had some bad experiences with other branded stuff. His pre-race meal was a liquid meal because he would wake up really full from all the carb loading he had done the day before. 3 hours before the race he would shake liquid maltodextrin with protein powder, and add a little bit of olive oil as a health fat to help slow things down a little. He would take a gel right on the starting line. He would be sipping on a water bottle the whole time. He would be able to put a water bottle on a table every 5K. These would start off dilute and get increasingly concentrated as the race went on. The reason for this is that the body absorbs things more easily when it’s not tired. He wanted to make sure he was front loading his carbon intake during the marathon because the body can process it a lot easier. When you’re 40K into a marathon, you don’t feel like taking in carbs at all. Often he would take a swig of a water bottle and spit it out; it tricks the body into thinking it’s getting carbs but it doesn’t get anything. This would give a little jolt of energy with just 2K to go. He would have a gel at 15K; at 30K he would have a caffeinated gel. He would time his caffeine intake to where he was taking it 75 minutes prior to the start of the race. Caffeine is really interesting; when it came on board he couldn’t imagine doing a race without it. There was no going back. He is 100% faster with caffeine on board than without it.

title: Tylenol as a performance enhancer
content: Peter asks if he ever experimented with Tylenol. No, Ryan never did. Peter was talking to Lance Armstrong about it a couple weeks ago and this came up. He never used Tylenol in the tour but it’s a pretty remarkable performance enhancing drug. Perfectly legal. It gives a 1-2% boost. It’s not clear if this comes through temperature reduction of pain reduction. Peter used it during time trials. A time trial is basically an hour of threshold; it’s super painful. Sometimes he felt like he even gained 3% from Tylenol. Peter would take 1000 mg before a race. He’s curious if other athletes have tried it. Ryan is not familiar with it but is definitely going to try it with his athletes now. Peter notes, Tylenol reduces pain in a way that is different from NSAIDs. One  needs to be careful with the dose because it’s a very liver toxic drug at high doses. But in normal amounts, 1000 mg is incredibly safe. Ryan asks if there is any application to lifting. If it keeps the core temperature down, it seems like that would be helpful. Peter hasn’t seen any literature on lifting with Tylenol. Funny story, about 8 years ago Peter saw some papers that looked at how Viagra improved lifting. So he tried it but couldn’t use Viagra because of the symptoms he was getting. It’s a vasodilator; his blood pressure isn’t high but is kind of low so he would get light-headed using it. But research shows that 25-50 mg of Viagra boosts muscle endurance and performance.

title: Maximizing Performance with Core Temperature
content: Keeping the core temperature cool can boost performance. Ryan asks if Peter has played at all with palm cooling. Peter used to check his core temperature before and after long swims because he had the opposite problem. Sometimes he would actually swim with a rectal probe just to see. Too much or too little temp is pretty bad. Ryan mentions Dr. Huberman, a Stanford neuroscientist who studies palm cooling. There is some pretty remarkable research about this and its effects on strength training and endurance. The best way to lower cort temp is through one’s face, the upper face where there is no hair. The next best is through the hands and bottoms of the feet. They developed this glove to dump heat. It’s not icy cold, just cool. One doesn’t want it too cold. It doesn’t change vasodilation. It dumps heat and brings the core temperature down. Ryan has been playing a little with holding a cold pack in his hands between lifts or putting his hands in cool water to dump his temp. If one can keep their temperatures in an optimal range, in theory, it should increase their endurance. Peter has tried a cooling helmet. The helmet had gel pack inserts that could be frozen in the freezer. When he would ride his trainer wearing this cooling helmet, it definitely made a difference. He couldn’t bring himself to use it in a race. Many people invest in a cooling vest; it’s a vest that runs ice water around one’s torso. Finally Peter got one and it was a game changer. Ryan is interested in this because he plays around with a cooling vest too. He has an archaic one that he freezes then it slowly gets back to temperature. Peter notes this would not be great for a runner because it would be too heavy. In a car, it’s an enormous performance booster. Using the cooling vest made a difference in how tired he felt after the race. It was the difference between feeling like one was going to die and feeling tired but okay. Peter can see how cooling could be used in strength training but wonders how it could be incorporated into a marathon. Ryan thinks cooling would be useful before a race when the athlete is warming-up, doing drills and strides. In interval training, cooling could be done between sets. He’ll use a bucket of cold water at the track for the athletes to put their hands in inbetween sets. He has used those instant cold packs; break them open and hold them for about 2 minutes. It’s kind of a hindrance, but it’s worth it to get the performance benefit.

title: Maximizing Deadlift Performance
content: You would probably see more benefit on your best 10 rep deadlift as opposed to a max deadlift.

title: Cold gloves and handlebars for athletes
content: Peter and Ryan discuss the potential benefits of using cold gloves and handlebars for athletes. Ryan mentions that he hasn't tried the gloves they have at Stanford, but he's curious about them. He knows they use it on the football team and a lot of the athletic programs. For the bike, it would be cool if they could make the handlebars colder. Peter agrees, this would be a great idea if they could make it really light.

title: Ryan's early struggles and later success at Stanford
content: Peter asks Ryan about his time at Stanford. Ryan talks about his background and how he was in the middle of 5 kids. His dad was a teacher and his mom was a stay at home mom. He thought running might take him to a good college; he was going to have to earn his way there. Ryan talks about his achievements at Stanford, including being part of a NCAA winning team, 2 years there in cross-country. In his 4th year at Stanford, things just clicked. He and his teammate Ian Dobson went 1, 2 in track. At that point he was having a very lackluster career at Stanford. Now everything was clicking and he had the opportunity to run professionally.

title: Ryan's struggle with depression
content: Ryan talks about his struggles with depression and how he left Stanford for a quarter in his sophomore year. He was going to go back home, but back at home he became even more depressed. He realized he was supposed to be back at Stanford. So he went back to Stanford and gradually things started to get better. It was a struggle athletically and academically until his 4th year. Then the doors came open to run professionally and he left the farm after that.

title: Running a mile in under 4 minutes
content: Peter and Ryan discuss the rarity of running a mile in under 4 minutes in high school. Ryan talks about his friendship with Alan Webb, who ran a 3:53 mile in high school. Alan went to Michigan and struggled his sophomore year.

title: Alan and Ryan's Running Careers
content: Alan set the American record in the mile [3:46.91]. Ryan set the American record in the half [marathon, 59:43]. They were roommates in Europe in 2006; they were racing and both struggling for various reasons. They both had very high highs and very low lows. They are similar, but Alan is definitely one of the most talented runners Ryan has ever seen.

title: Ryan's Training Approach
content: Ryan has always been very interested in the nuts and bolts of training. It’s important to understand how he’s doing what he’s doing as an athlete. He has a tendency to try to prove himself to himself in training. He wants to know if he’s fit and ready to go. Sometimes he’s going harder in training than racing. But this isn’t the best way for his body to absorb the work. He’s in a much better place if he going into these workouts confident in who he is, knowing the purpose of the workout.

title: Ryan's Mindset and Faith
content: In his senior year, his identity was all wrapped up in his performances. This is why he struggled with depression. He would look in the mirror in the morning, he was struggling with running, he was hurt. He was frustrated with how things were going; he wasn’t getting better. Focusing on his faith helped him change his mindset. He decided he was going to choose on a daily basis. He discovered he could love himself whether he had a great workout or a bad workout; he became cool with who he was. That just took the weight off. It made him fearless too.

title: Ryan's Shift in Training Approach
content: As Ryan’s approach to his workouts changed, thing started to click a lot better. Another big thing he learned is that he didn’t have to beat his work or his teammates in training anymore. Instead, he could just work with them. He didn’t have to try to drop them, even if he could. He became secure in who he was. This was a huge shift but results didn’t come all of a sudden. This took years and years to turn into something.

title: Improving Communication Helped Ryan Be a Better Teammate
content: Ryan used to come to every workout in the mode of hammer time, which probably alienated a lot of teammates. He would train his brains out and would come back blasting everyone all the time. This changed for Ryan as he was able to communicate and work with the team better. In a group environment, it’s crazy how just that little communication can really shift the dynamics of the group.

title: Ryan’s Professional Running Career and His Discovery of His Gift for Marathon Distances
content: Ryan turned pro in 2005 with ASICS as his lead sponsor. He never thought he would run a marathon and focused on speed and the 5K. After spending a year in college focusing on his 5K, he didn’t improve. He needed to figure out his vision for running and tried to figure out what event he would be most competitive at. He had an openness to longer distances where before he was very closed minded and focused on running a world-class mile.

title: The Path to Marathon Running
content: Ryan had run zero half marathons before Houston in 2007, which was his first. He had run a couple of 20Ks, which is just 1K less than a half marathon. He got worked on the track that first year and realized that the 5K wasn’t his best event. This realization allowed him to start experimenting with longer distances. In the summer, he started training for longer distances and did the World 20K Championships then the US National 20K Championships. In the winter, he got into marathon training and was planning to debut in the Los Angeles Marathon.

title: The 2007 Half Marathon in Houston
content: Ryan's first half marathon was in Houston in January 2007. At the time, the American record for a half marathon was 1 hour and 55 seconds. This was in the days before GPS watches so he had written down on his hands 3 different categories of times he was going for.

title: Ryan Hall's American Record Half Marathon
content: Ryan Hall ran the half marathon in 59:43, obliterating the American record by over a minute. He ran the first mile in 5:35, and it felt too easy. He kept pushing and waiting for it to get hard, but it never did. He had one issue around mile 9 where his stomach got a little bit turny, but it passed a couple of minutes later. He wonders what he could have run that day if he had a pacemaker and if it was a full marathon. Looking back on it, this is why he is such a big proponent of speed now.

title: Ryan Hall's Reflections on Breaking the American Half Marathon Record
content: Ryan Hall reflects on breaking the American half marathon record and says that breaking 60 was a lifetime goal, and to do it on his first half marathon was crazy. He got a huge hit of adrenaline when he crossed the finish line. He had the sensation of 'We did this.' It wasn't special because he felt like he had done something incredible. Instead, it was 'We all did this thing together; and it was just an amazing lifetime moment that I'll never forget.'

title: Ryan Hall's Athletic Achievements
content: Ryan Hall went from a decent track athlete to a top 10 all-time performer for a half marathon. He realized he had a chance of medaling in Beijing. He found his giftedness and purpose, which was a cool moment of realizing he was in the club with the best guys in the world. After that, he never showed up in another race thinking he couldn’t win or not having high expectations for the race. Houston in 2007 was his best half marathon, and 4 years later was his best marathon (2:04:58 in the 2011 Boston Marathon).

title: Savoring the Moment
content: Ryan Hall had a moment of realization that it’s okay for his athletic career to not last forever. He savored it for everything it is worth and tells his athletes to savor every second of it. He notes that removing oneself from performance can be super helpful in some ways. He enjoys performances and loves seeing growth and going after big goals. He still loves seeing growth and thinks this is something that helps people transition out of this sport.

title: Ryan Hall's Perspective on Athletic Achievements
content: For a long time, Ryan Hall was all wrapped up in his performance. He enjoys performances and loves seeing growth and going after big goals. Running was just an expression of who he is; it was like his painting. Now he has moved on to lifting and crazy challenges. He loves physical challenge and expresses himself now through lifting. He thinks what humans want is having that experience. When one loses the ability to express themselves, things can get dark pretty quick. He believes that as long as we’re continually finding ways to be ourselves and to express ourselves, we’re going to be happy individuals.

title: Ryan’s Mammoth Track Club Training Regimen
content: Ryan trained at the Mammoth Track Club in 2010, where he did intervals on Tuesdays, working on 5K-specific speed. He did things like 6 by mile, 10 by K, 800 meter repeats, and 400 meter repeats. He experimented with new styles of training that he had never done before. He had always been in the same routine, doing the same structured training.

title: Ryan's Transition and New Training Style
content: Ryan left the Mammoth Track Club in 2010 and decided to have God as his coach. He spent a lot of time in prayer trying to connect with God. He got the revelation, “It’s not about what I do. It’s about how I do what I do.” He experimented with new styles of training that he had never done before. New stimulus is always helpful for the body.

title: Ryan's Warm-up and Workout Routine
content: Ryan's warm-up routine consisted of an easy 20-minute jog around at an 8 minute mile pace. He would do some dynamic flexibility or maybe some static stuff. He would spend 5-10 minutes on drills and strides. Then he would change into his racing shoes and go straight into the workout. He would keep the rest fairly short; within the mile he would rest 90 seconds to 2 minutes. Sometimes he’s doing a slow walk-jog, it depends.

title: Running Workouts
content: The moderate part would be at 8-minute pace or even faster, 7-minute pace. Then for the fast part, the goal is a 5K pace or slightly slower than a mile pace. There are a lot of different variations that they would take on those workouts. The cool-down would be 20 minutes.

title: Ice Bathing
content: The science on the ice bath has changed quite a bit. Now the science is showing the benefits of having the body to respond to the inflammation first. Now they don’t do a ton of ice baths. But there are a whole bunch of other good, positive effects of ice bathing, like dopamine going up tenfold.

title: Training Schedule
content: He would come back in the afternoon for a 30-35 minute easy run then go straight to the weight room and do leg lifts. A mistake he sees a lot of runners make is to do all their leg stressors on the same day. Ideally, do the hard run in the morning and come back in the afternoon to do the weights. After a day like this, he would head home to eat and go to bed early.

title: Sleeping Habits
content: Ryan notes that, “Pro runners are very lazy people from day to day. We don’t go for walks or hikes or do anything. It’s just train, eat, sleep, stay off your feet. And you’re always aware of that energy expenditure. You’re trying to save as much as you can for your training.” He would book every day from 1-3 pm for a nap. He would probably sleep 9-10 hours every night.

title: Optimal Body Weight
content: Intense training is hard on the body. Peter notes that cyclists have to work hard and deliberately restrict calories. Often they would show up to huge stage races like the Tour de France, the Giro, the Alta, calorie depleted. Ryan agrees, his lifestyle and training was very specific. Training at that level wasn’t the most healthy lifestyle; it wasn’t optimal for his health. Thinking of weight, Ryan is 5’ 10” and his weight got down as low as 127 lbs. He noticed his running got worse if he was less than 137 lbs.

title: Healthy Weight Gain
content: Ryan would take a 2-week break where he wouldn’t run at all. It was like a donut-eating competition for 2 weeks straight. He would literally put on over 10 lbs in that 2-week period. It wasn’t good for him emotionally or mentally, but it worked every single time for his build up. He should have taken a more healthy approach to putting on weight, to being good to his body. He should have shifted his macros around during that time off and gained weight in a healthy way.

title: Training Volume and Intensity
content: Peter asks what his weekly mileage was. It was probably around 110 or so; this was pre-Garmin days. There’s a place for running the same all the time but it’s not going to get you to the next level. To really see how good you can get, one needs to have super hard days and easy, super chill days. Sometimes Ryan runs 12 miles in under a 5 minute pace. The next day he will do an easy run— 8m, 30 pace. Having that variance between pacing is super important. This allows one to stress the body, then rest the body (keep repeating the cycle). The body will adapt. Peter agrees; proper training is one thing he spends a lot of time talking about with patients. Most people are training in this garbage zone where it’s too high in intensity to build a true aerobic foundation, and too low in intensity to truly stress the body glycolytically. Then at the other end of the spectrum, there’s got to be this real push pace, a 4 by  4 pace. 4 on and 4 off. Most people aren’t used to that level of discomfort; there are 2 problems. 1) Training in a physiologic no man’s land. 2) There’s no variability in the intensity of the workouts. “I don’t think enough people understand both for performance and also longevity why you have to be at the more extremes of zone 2; zone 5 is where the progress comes” – Peter Attia

title: Caffeine
content: Ryan notes that caffeine helps; he recommends only having caffeine before hard training days. Then on the easy day it feels like death because you’re tired fromt he workout but also because of the lack of caffeine. Peter notes that some athletes really benefit from caffeine; he never felt that. He can have coffee at any time of day; it has no bearing on his sleep. So he gets no up from it, no down from it. There are different genes that are responsible for caffeine metabolism. So people do vary in that.

title: Ryan Hall's Training Leading Up to the 2011 Boston Marathon
content: Ryan Hall made some impactful adjustments to his training leading up to the 2011 Boston Marathon. He spaced out his workouts, running intervals on Tuesday and a long threshold on Friday, with 2 easy days before that. The threshold run is a constant pace, slightly higher than race pace but a shorter distance. He would do 3 of these every week, for 12 weeks building up to the marathon. Generally speaking, whatever you can run for that 15 mile threshold, you can hold for a marathon. The long run occurs when there is already a little bit of fatigue in the legs. Sometimes he would run over the marathon distance. These are high quality efforts. Oftentimes its at a medium pace, 6-minute mile for the first half and slower on the second half.

title: Ryan Hall's Tweaks to His Formula After 2011
content: Ryan Hall started spacing things out a little bit more, taking 2 easy days between every session. He was focused on a 9-10-day cycle but was making those workouts higher quality, bigger. Sometimes instead of those short Tuesday sessions he would do 20 by 1000 meters with a 200-meter easy job between each 1000 meter. This was done at a faster than marathon pace. His marathon target pace was 3 minutes per kilometer. This workout pace would be 2:55; 5 seconds per K. He loved this workout for marathon training.

title: Ryan Hall's Use of Cross Training
content: Ryan Hall utilizes cross training more now as a coach than when he was running. He would go to cross training when he would get a little pain. Foot pain, knee pain; little things just pop up. This is usually what would cause him to miss a workout. When he was a runner, he was just kind of the old school, run or die kind of mentality, which is not a helpful mentality to have.

title: Lessons on maximizing your own potential
content: Ryan Hall talks about how he had a terrible half marathon a month before the Boston Marathon, but he got back up and started training again. He came out of this race and started feeling phenomenal; it was a very quick change. He took his training to the next level. He started having caffeine every single day; this was the first time in his career he started doing this. He started running his easy runs a lot quicker. He was just floating through it at a 5:30, 5:20 pace. Even the day before the race, he did an easy 30-minute run plus 6 x 100 meter strides. That was a custom run of his before the marathon. He felt like a million bucks going into Boston.

title: Cycling between training at altitude and sea level
content: Ryan Hall spent 2 months up at altitude, dropped down to sea level for a month; go back up, drop back down. He took this idea from Jack Daniels who has done a ton of research in the running space. Daniels is probably one of the most brilliant minds in running. He said this type of training produces a dramatic increase in hematocrit, hemoglobin, early on in those 1st 3 weeks and then it just starts to taper off. This goes back down at sea level. But when you go back up to altitude again, it produces another big dramatic shift. The goal is to keep shifting up. There are positives to training at sea level. He sleeps better at sea level. He runs faster. He can do workouts at sea level he can’t do at altitude.

title: Talk of a tailwind foreshadows his record-breaking race
content: Ryan Hall remembers talking to one of the race organizers the day before the race; she mentioned they were supposed to get a good tailwind for the race. Ryan just lit up inside when he heard this because he gets excited about running fast. Ryan remembers talking to Bill Rodgers (who won the Boston Marathon 4 times and the New York Marathon 4 times). Bill told him, “about once every 10 years you get a wicked tailwind in Boston, then you can really roll”. Bill had a year when he got a tailwind, he stopped 4 times in the race to tie his shoe, to walk, to get water, and he still ran 2:09. These words were in Ryan’s head at the starting line in Hopkinton that morning.

title: Ryan Hall's Boston Marathon Race
content: Ryan Hall ran the Boston Marathon race with the intention of getting everything he could out of every single mile. He was under the world record pace and ran a lot of his miles at 4:30. The first half of the race was slightly down, and he had the wind at his back. The last part of the race was challenging, with hills from mile 17.5 through mile 20. Ryan finished fourth and ran 2:04:58. He put his hands out and soaked it all in, yelled super loud, and felt he’d won the race even though he hadn’t.

title: Ryan Hall's Last Mile
content: Ryan Hall's last mile was a blur, and he was in serious pain. He saw 2 hours flat and thought, 'okay, if I break 5 minutes for this last mile, I’m going to be under 2:05.' His PR at the time was 2:06:17, and he was already going to run a big PR no matter what. He put his head down, grit his teeth, and bore it, trying to break five and get under 2:05. The crowds in Boston were just insane, and he'll never forget running down Boylston Street, and the crowds just going crazy. He felt he’d won the race even though he hadn’t.

title: Learning from failure and takeaways from his disappointing performance at the 2012 Olympics
content: Peter remarks, “the most amazing part of your journey is not the successes. It’s the way in which you’ve been able to kind of carry yourself through the failures.” Going into the 2012 Olympics in London after Boston, there is this parallel between ’07 and ’08; and then again in ’11 and ’12. In how he was feeling going into London, the expectations early in that season were very high. Ryan agrees, coming out of a 2:04, he was going to take a shot at winning this race, even though he’d just been beaten by a minute by those guys. He knew he wasn’t expected to necessarily win, but he knew he had a shot. If you run 2:04 for the marathon, in those days, you have a chance to win a gold medal.

title: Talking about not putting on the weight after he ran London
content: Talking about not putting on the weight after he ran London, this was a theme going back to Beijing. Leading up to the buildup for Beijing and he did the same thing; and it made his training run flat. This is where having a coach is a helpful thing. If he would’ve told a coach what he was going to do, the coach would say, “That’s a really bad idea. Let’s just stick with what we know works for you in this situation. And that’s putting on 10 pounds.” But instead of doing that … his heart was good, his intentions were good. He really wanted to hear God, and a way that people across all traditions do this is through fasting. So instead of putting on 10 pounds, he did a 1-week fast.

title: Preparing for London and lessons learned about not depleting his body
content: Preparing for London and lessons learned about not depleting his body. Boston was April 15th; the Olympics were in August. There was enough time for him to get a full buildup for the game. But he wanted clarity on how to train for this thing. So instead of his weight going from 137 to 150 during that 2-week period, it went from 137 to 130 flat. He started the training in a really depleted state. His body wasn’t in a good state. Mentally and spiritually, he was in the best spot he’d ever been. But his body wasn’t ready to go at all; it needed a break after that. He began his training and was running pretty well initially, but it went downhill from there. It became a miracle that he even made it to the starting line, considering how poorly his training was going. And this is what he tells himself in the weight room all the time now. When he’s getting stale in training and not seeing growth. If he’s not taking in enough calories; it doesn’t matter how he’s training, it’s not going to work. That’s how it was for him in that buildup, his body was depleted. He didn’t have enough calories on board. It was a frustrating period of training leading up to that. He took his watch off for all his workouts because it was so discouraging to see how slow he was running compared to what he was accustomed to. It was helpful to get away from the data but it wasn’t enough to get his body back into the state it needed to be in.

title: Optimism at the start of London but injury leads him to drop out
content: He’s a very optimistic person, so he’s pretty good at generating hope, and there was some genuine hope at the starting line in London. Sometimes training can go really badly and then, pop, you can have one big day. He always has the thought that something special could happen today. But early on in the race the pace felt super hard, super fast. This is often the case when he gets too lean and too light; then he has injury issues. Luckily his chiropractor, John Ball, had him in one piece at the starting line. But early in the race his right hamstring started hurting, and that’s ultimately what led him to drop out as I was in the middle of that race. He was already starting to limp a little seven miles into the race. He had to be smart, because this is his livelihood, and he’s looking out for the long term.

title: Being good to his body
content: He wants to be good to his body and take care of himself.

title: Dropping out of the London Marathon
content: Ryan Hall dropped out of the London Marathon, which was the first race he ever dropped out of. He remembers the second loop when he dropped out and began the long process of working through that mentally and emotionally.

title: Mourning London and restoring hope with the next challenge
content: After dropping out of the London Marathon, Ryan Hall had a period of mourning the loss and then decided the next thing he was going after. He had a little meeting with himself of things he was going to tweak, to do differently, to do better. Then he decided to go back after this sub-5 minute mile and sub-5 deadlift.

title: Belief is important
content: Belief is important for athletes to believe in their coach. If you don’t think it’s going to work, it doesn’t matter what’s prescribed, it’s probably not going to work.

title: Injuries
content: Ryan Hall had a problem with compensation issues, which is common in runners. He had an issue in his upper high hamstring where it attaches, but he just ran through it. He had a lot of injuries from 2012 through his retirement in 2016. Looking back on it, a big piece of it was nutrition. Physically, this was killing him. If he could go back, he would take more time off.

title: Taking Time Off and Recovery
content: He would take 3 months completely off and not run at all. At the time he thought this suggestion was crazy. But it would have been super helpful, just to get away from it and get his body back into a good spot. Why Ryan feels so much better physically and mentally nowadays. Recovery and weight lifting. His body has been restored.

title: Weight Lifting and Hormonal Health
content: Lifting has helped him give back to his body. Lifting is something he’s not genetically gifted at, but he loves the challenge. Ryan notes that hormonal health really affects mental health, motivation, and energy levels. For him, this is where weightlifting comes in. He knows a lot of runners don’t want to lift weights; he was the same way. But there are ways around this. BFR (blood flow restriction) is one approach. There are healthy ways to lift weights.

title: Running Specific Strength Training
content: For runners, he loves to prescribe hex bar deadlifts with the handles up. This way you’re not going down as low. You’re not loading up the lower back as much. He loves half squats for the same reason. A lot of running is just hip extension. Every time your foot contacts the ground, your hips have to extend to get out of that position. So we need to do things that really focus on that; half squats are great for that. Get the bone benefits of loading up a bar and having it on your back, and avoid stress reactions. Get your bone density up that way and just feel really good coming out.

title: BFR Training
content: He’s been playing around a lot with BFR. He thinks BFR is a way for runners who are maybe skinny, or more concerned about getting hurt, to get the same benefits of lifting heavy without having to put a bunch of weight on the bar. Peter comments that a couple weeks ago he did some sets on the Airdyne Bike with heavy BFR on his upper thighs. He wonders if this would translate to running. He can’t really walk when he’s in the full BFR. Ryan thinks this is interesting and is going to try BFR on a run.

title: Performance Enhancing Drugs in Marathon Runners
content: Peter asks about drug use in running; for competitive cycling drug use is the norm. Why is it that marathon runners, who would benefit from tons of performance enhancing drugs (PEDs), traditionally haven’t used them? Ryan thinks it’s the culture.

title: Performance Enhancing Drugs in Running
content: Ryan has never heard of anyone talking about performance enhancing drugs or having access to them in the US. However, he has heard about it in Kenya and there have been guys busted all over the world. EPO is the drug of choice, and there is a lot of gray line stuff too. Ryan was involved with a doping case that supposedly went down, but he didn’t follow it closely.

title: Traits of the Greatest Marathon Runners
content: Ryan notes that highly motivated individuals who are highly genetically gifted make great runners. There are some theories about a small pelvis being helpful for distance running. Ryan reminisces about running next to Haile Gebrselassie, one of the greatest distance runners of all time. He thinks that Africans can run a lot faster than they’re running and is curious about their approach to training versus our approach. Maybe a blend of these two approaches is best.

title: What Makes Kipchoge So Great
content: Ryan thinks that Kipchoge is perhaps the greatest marathon runner today. He is genetically gifted but also humble. Kipchoge balances being fearless and controlled, which sets him apart when you read about his training. He’s always talking about running like 80% max and everything being super controlled. Ryan hasn’t gotten results with that type of training, but it works for Kipchoge.

title: Ryan Hall's Mentality
content: Ryan Hall's mental approach to training and racing is the most composed I've ever seen in an athlete.

title: Sub 2 Hour Marathon
content: Without a doubt. We're seeing huge performances like this. With the new technology people are running two minutes faster over the marathon with these shoes on. What people think is possible now has just been blown up. Now people are trying insane stuff, like a sub-2 hour marathon. That would have never happened without these shoes.

title: 7 Marathons in 7 Days on 7 Continents
content: Peter recounts some of Ryan's stunts—7 marathons in 7 days on 7 continents sounds ridiculous. But it's made more ridiculous by the fact that he didn't train for it. Ryan was retired from pro running when one of his pastor friends from LA (Matthew Barnett) texted him about this challenge. Something about it captured Ryan, and he felt like he did at 13 when he was going on that first big run around Big Bear Lake. He was doing zero runs at this point; he was only in the weight room, focused on strength. He ended up joining this challenge.

title: Training for 7 Marathons in 7 Days on 7 Continents
content: He started training because if he was going to do this, he wanted to enjoy it. He didn't enjoy the training. He started getting a lot of the same fatigue issues that came with professional running. So he decided to stop training and enjoy his life for the 9 months leading up to this. He ran 3 days a week, between 5-8 miles. 8 miles was his longest run leading up to this challenge where he was going to run 183 miles in 1 week. This is by far the most he's ever run in a week. Prior to this maybe he ran 140 miles. This challenge involved hopping on airplanes.

title: Details of the Challenge
content: It was a trip of a lifetime. There was a group of 30 of them. Richard Donovan put it on; it's called the World Marathon Challenge. The trip and the challenge cost about $40,000.

title: Antarctica Marathon
content: It starts in Antarctica; this was the coolest marathon. It was a 7 mile loop course. He thought it was going to be flat and just white. There were all these mountains. They were on a glacier. They had to take a Russian airplane to get there. It looked like something out of a movie. He felt pretty good during the run. His idea was to take in 50 g of protein every 7 miles or so because he didn't want to lose his gains. This is the opposite of what he usually does. Usually he takes in simple sugar. With this new nutrition by mile 23 he is completely out of it; he needed sugar stat. His protein bar hardly has any carbs in it. At a support tent (which was unmanned) they had laid out dried fruit and candy. He crawls in there and grabs as much candy as he can. He started feeling better immediately. He learned his lesson. He thinks he ran that marathon in 3:30 or so. Peter comments on how amazing this is; 3:30 is still fast for a marathon.

title: Chile Marathon
content: The second marathon was in Chile. They got to sleep in a hotel that night which was nice. There were only 2 nights during the week where they got to sleep in a hotel room. That marathon felt pretty good. Antarctica was supposed to be really cold, but it didn't feel that bad. Maybe it was a dry cold. He wore his regular run stuff that he would use in Flagstaff in the wintertime. Full tights, long sleeve, a shell jacket, and gloves/ mittens, and a beanie. He wasn't sweating at all. They say you don't want to sweat because it freezes on you and can cause hypothermia. He was good. He thinks his time in Chile was a little bit faster than Antarctica but not a lot.

title: Antarctica
content: Antarctica was nice because running on the snow doesn’t beat up your legs; it’s a little bit softer. He also used the most cushy shoe he could find because he knew his legs were going to take a beating. He weighed around 170 at the time.

title: Miami
content: They flew to Miami and that was fun; it was like a homecoming back in the states but also warm. He had more trouble with this one. Maybe he ran Miami at 3:30 or something.

title: Spain
content: They flew to Spain. He had the words day ever in Spain. Luckily one of his Dutch friends came over and rode his bike with him on this run. “Even when I was running professionally running can be your best friend and your greatest enemy all at the same time” – Ryan Hall.

title: Morocco
content: Morocco was for Africa. They got a hotel room for that one. Considering how bad he felt in Spain, his goal was to start out super chill and just make it through this one. “The mystery of running, why you’d all of a sudden feel so good? I have no idea, but I just started feeling like a million bucks.” – Ryan Hall. He started out chill but started feeling good, like his old self. He was mentally super engaged, he started charging, and came home super quick. He ended up running this one around 3:04. Which for zero training was really good. From then on he was pumped.

title: Dubai
content: Dubai was the sixth marathon. The problem after Morocco was he developed a bit of a limp; his hip was bothering him. He thought he could shake it off. But in Dubai his hip was on fire and he knew something was really wrong. He ended up walking the back half of that marathon. His time was probably over 4 hours.

title: Sydney
content: Sydney was the last marathon. When they landed in Sydney he tries to stand and put weight on the leg where the hip was bothering him and the pain took his breath away. The pain was super sharp. He knew he was in trouble. He was also sick of all the tiny things you do as a pro runner. Mobility stretching, etc. He wasn’t doing any of this. He didn’t wear compression socks the entire week. When he got to Sydney his ankles looked like elephant ankles, they were so swollen. In Sydney he put on the same singlet he wore at his first marathon in London in 2006 or 2007. He was thinking, “this is my last marathon…this is my goodbye tour”. He went in with the same attitude he had for his 15 mile run around Big Bear. He wanted to go out with a bang. “I never got to say goodbye to the sport. It’s like, I just faded out. And all of a sudden I was gone and my body wasn’t able to run.” – Ryan  Hall. This was his chance to say goodbye to the sport that he loved. The last marathon was at Manly beach. They did a mile out, mile back for the whole marathon. It was sick, the beach was lit up by the moon and the stars. They were running at 1:00 am for some reason. He would have rather gotten more sleep. He thinks Richard scheduled the run at night was to give people enough time to finish. He needed the extra time that day. He got a massage in the middle of the run. When he got home and had a MRI he found out he had a stress reaction in his hip. Massages aren’t the best for a stress reaction. He’ll never forget coming across that finish line. The sun was up. It took him 5.5 hours. It was the longest, slowest, most painful marathon. Every time he put his leg down on that concrete he felt the zing of a super sharp pain. But after running 6 marathons in a row he was like, “I’m doing whatever it takes to get through this seventh one. I’m not stopping now and never signing up for this trip again. So I got to get it done.” He came across the finish line, took off his shoes and left them there.

title: The Symbolic Finish
content: This was a finish he stole from Olympic wrestlers who leave their shoes on the mat after they have wrestled their last match. It was a symbolic way of saying, “I’ve given everything I have to give…it’s over, I’m walking away”.

title: The Importance of People in Running
content: “I was tearing up as I was walking back to the hotel just because running gave me so many gifts. It was so life altering for me and the most beautiful part of all of it was the people. Meeting my wife, my kids, all the people I crossed paths with continue.” – Ryan Hall. The people he met are what he holds most dear from that experience. What’s cool about it is that it doesn’t matter what level you run at. We all get to experience that when you sign up for any race. You’re out there with a 50,000 amazing people that are on a journey with you. We get to do it together.

title: The Transition to Coaching
content: That whole sentiment just hit him super hard; saying goodbye to the sport he loves. But then, it’s been such a beautiful transition though of realizing that that whole season was about seeing how good he could get. Since then he’s realized it wasn’t just for him. Everything he’s learned in that season was meant to be passed down. It was meant to be shared and meant to help other people. This launched him into the season coaching. Coaching his wife, coaching other athletes in person. He started Run Free Training where he coaches runners of every single discipline. Every level. Super slow people. Middle school kids. Because it doesn’t matter where you’re at, we just want to be on the journey with you and we want to guide you and help you on your journey.

title: Helping People Live Happier
content: So it was really special to realize that even all the mistakes that he made, they weren’t for naught. He’s on this podcast, he’s able to share it with the listeners. And hopefully they won’t make the same mistakes and they’ll be better off for it. That is his goal now— how he can help people. Not just with running but with living. Living happier. He’s far more concerned with his athletes happiness than with how fast they are. “I want them to enter into the good life. And I think running is a way to do that. Lifting can be a way to do that, it adds to that, but more than anything I just want them to find joy.” – Ryan Hall.

title: The Grand Canyon
content: Peter comments that he would love to meet Ryan in person. They would have fun lifting together. He would love to try some of the crazy challenges Ryan has done. He wouldn’t be able to do the farmers-carry up the grand Canyon with a fraction of the weight Ryan used. This is something he could see wanting to do one day. The Grand Canyon is an amazing place. Peter has only been there once, but it’s still one of the most significant things he’s ever done. When he was there, he made it a hiking / swimming trip. He swam in the Colorado river and then in each of the waterfalls on the way up. There are thes 4 huge waterfalls that get progressively smaller as you go up.
